awd_titl_txt: Engaging Howard University Computer Science Students in Interactive Human-Centered Computing Infused Curricula
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program provides support to design, implement, study and assess efforts to increase the numbers of students and the quality of their preparation by strengthening science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and research. This project at Howard University provides a strategic approach to infuse courses and research with interactive, human-centered computing elements to engage and excite students about computer science with the goal to increase the number of computer science graduates. Undergraduate students are involved in this project as researchers. 

This one-year pilot project seeks to redesign the Introduction to Game Design course and Introduction to Human-Computer Interaction course in the computer science undergraduate curriculum with learning modules in mixed reality, including virtual reality and augmented reality; along with user experience design and fundamentals of human-computer interaction.  These courses will give students exposure to interactive computing elements using active, project-based learning.  The project will study the efficacy of this intervention using qualitative and quantitative measures. The project will be guided by formative and summative evaluation.

This project is co-funded by the Division of Information and Intelligent Systems in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
This Targeted Infusion initiative was focused on increasing undergradute computer science students by engaging them in human-centered computing or interactive computing projects in their introductory programming courses and within the elective computing courses liking gaming, human-computer interaction, or affective computing at Howard University. 

This project created the following opportunities for students at Howard University:

1) Participation in innovation challenges like Games for Change and CMD-IT Innovation Challenge where they placed nationally in the conference,

2) Crreation of the Linear Algebra for Robotics course to replace their regular Linear Alebra Course,

3) Research Experiences for Undergraduate students to learn how to read research papers, author research papers, and present scientific research findings for an interdisciplinary audience 

4) Travel support to scientific conferences including the Conference on Research in Equity and Sustained Participation in Engineering, Computing, and Technology (RESPECT), the Richard Tapia Conference, and the Grace Hopper Celebration of Computing,

5) Industry co-taught courses including Foundations of User Experience Design Human-Computer Interaction, and User Experience Practicum, and 

6) Free Coursera access to the Google User Experience Design Certificate, 

7) Industry User Interface certificate through the General Services Administration, and 

8) Access to Collaborations with Carnegie Mellon, Michigan, and Northwestern to create joint degrees in HCI, robotics, and computer science, and

9) Access to faculty experts in interactive computing, gaming, and computer science through distributed teaching provided by Michigan, Carnegie Melllon, and Northwestern.

Because of this Targeted Infusion project, Howard Computer Science program has increased the course enrollment of Human-Computer interaction course from a meager ten students to about 25 students per semester. Additionally, the HCI course was originally offered in only one semester to undergraduate students, but it is now offered every semester. Finally, the student performance in the course has led to students obtaiing an average grade of 90% and creating artificats that students can use to acquire entry-level user experience design fulltime positions and internships.

Finally, Howard University was able to be awarded the Richard Tapia University Award for its effort for retaining and recruiting Black and Brown computer science students. Additionally the PI was able to leverage feedback and appreciation from her Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) students in her appliction for the NCWIT Undergraduate Research Mentoring Award. She was awarded this honor after working with more 20 students per academic year for the three years of the grant. 

In conclusion, this Targeted Infusion Project has led to a renewed sense of pride in the Computer Science program. More students participate in research projects, write scientific posters for presenting in and outside of Howard,and enjoy more engaging curriculum that includes interactive computing, gaming, and human-computer interaction techniques. 


Last Modified: 07/11/2023
Modified by: Gloria Washington
